Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Alexander A. Young is " The Growth of Algebras." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Washington, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. James Zhang.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research in the field of mathematics is a path laid one brick at a time. While some of these bricks -- theorems and facts proven to be true -- are famous, immediately recognizable, powerful, or succinct, most of them are esoteric and difficult to summarize in layman's terms. But, when a multitude of them are placed together, each building off the last, they can reach to planes of knowledge otherwise inaccessible.

Unlike an actual engineered pathway, it is seldom clear where a mathematical path is headed when you place these bricks. But very much like a real pathway from town to town, once it is completed, it can be trod upon for centuries, even taken from granted by those that use it and possibly rely on it for their livelihood. While calculus may appear stultifyingly abstract to a new learner, a rocket scientist would have to find a different career without it. 

Algebra, in particular, is an area of study well-acquainted with abstraction. A perusal of an algebra paper by those not well-versed in the art will reveal a worrying lack of actual written numbers. But after all, what is the use of numbers? The equation "2+2=4" is a mere placeholder for any real-world situation in which you find yourself with 2 items, and gain 2 others. Abbreviating “two cows and two cows make four cows together” by removing the word “cows” from the sentence makes the sentence less immediately accessible, but much more powerful. There is an inherent structure to the set of numbers that can be applied, whether it’s cows, dollars, or meters per second. 

In some situations, other structures are needed. There are cases in which it is desired to add or multiply things that aren't numbers, but obey some, but not all, of the rules of arithmetic. Consider a circle rotating freely: by partially rotating it two separate times, you are "adding" the two rotations together -- but this sum starts over when the circle has been turned completely around. Moving up a dimension, a freely rotating sphere presents a similar problem, but a much more complicated answer. For this reason, mathematicians invented quaternions: a set of a different kind of numbers that have their own rules of addition and multiplication. While they only exist as abstractions (much like basic numbers), their structure exactly matches what is needed to describe rotations in three-dimensional space.

The technical name of such a structure is an algebra. Each algebra has its own rules and properties, such as how multiplication works, or whether the numbers "loop around" after a certain point. The algebraist, then, is somewhat of a curator of these algebras. A question can be asked, such as whether or not there exist algebras that follow a set of specifications, or whether or not a certain condition holds uniformly on a certain species of algebra. These conditions and specifications are generally rather technical and difficult to summarize without symbols and formulas. 

One rich area of study is the concept of the automorphism. An automorphism of an algebra is a blueprint for transforming all its terms, each from one to another, in a way that preserves the underlying structure. Generally, the gamut of automorphisms available to a more sophisticated algebra can be quite complicated, perhaps even more so than the algebra itself! Any method we unlock to find some of these automorphisms for algebras is valued, and any rule we find to establish which ones don't exist, even more so. 

The published work that was completed under this award concerns the discriminant: an element of the algebra that is "fixed in place", and never moves when the rest of the algebra is transformed. Depending on the algebra, the identity of the discriminant may tell you nothing, or it might give you enough information to get the entire set of automorphisms outright. The first published paper, "Discriminant Formulas and Applications", looks specifically at the category of "q-quantum Weyl algebras". The other paper, "Discriminants and Automorphism Groups of Veronese Subrings of Skew Polynomial Rings", looks at a different category (as mentioned by name in the title). Both of these papers lay out in-depth criteria for determining when the automorphisms of one of these algebras are similar and easily numbered, or when they are myriad and come in many different flavors. 

Writing a full explanation of what these algebras are, the criteria for determining the character of their automorphisms, and maps of all such automorphisms, is well beyond the capability of the brief summary you are currently reading. Direct use of these esoteric results by laymen or even by other branches of science is unlikely. But the work has already been cited by other mathematics publications. As per routine for mathematics, the full appraisal of this work will only become clear with time.
